text: Math 257-316 PDE Formula sheet - ﬁnal exam Power series and analytic functions: (t can be a complex number) A function f (x) is analytic at a point x0 if it has a power series expansion in powers of x − x0 with radius R > 0, f (x) = ∑∞ n=0 an(x − x0) n, |x − x0| < R, R > 0. The sum and product of analytic functions are still analytic. Their quotient is also analytic if the denominator is nonzero. The new function has a radius of convergence no smaller than the minimum of those of the original functions. 1 1−t = ∑∞ m=0 tm, et = ∑∞ k=0 1 k! tk. cos t = ∑∞ m=0 (−1)m (2m)! t2m = eit+e−it 2 , sin t = ∑∞ m=0 (−1)m (2m+1)! t2m+1 = eit−e−it 2i . cosh t = ∑∞ m=0 1 (2m)! t2m = et+e−t 2 , sinh t = ∑∞ m=0 1 (2m+1)! t2m+1 = et−e−t 2 . e ix = cos x + i sin x, cos t = cosh(it), i sin t = sinh(it). ln(1 + t) = ∑∞ k=1 (−1)k−1 k tk, ln(1 − t) = − ∑∞ k=1 1 k tk. Its Fourier series is F f (x) = a0 + ∞∑ n=1 { an cos( nπx L ) + bn sin( nπx L ) } where a0 = 1 2L ∫ L −L f (x) dx, an = 1 L ∫ L −L f (x) cos( nπx L ) dx, bn = 1 L ∫ L −L f (x) sin( nπx L ) dx (n ≥ 1). F f (x) is deﬁned for all real x and is a 2L-periodic function. Theorem (Pointwise convergence) If f (x) and f ′(x) are piecewise con- tinuous, then F f (x) converges for every x to 1 2 [f (x−) + f (x+)]. Theorem (Square norm convergence) If f (x) is square integrable, i.e., ∫ L −L |f (x)| 2dx < ∞. Then F f (x) converge to f (x) in square norm, i.e. ∫ L −L |f (x) − Fnf (x)| 2dx → 0 as n → ∞, here Fnf (x) denotes the partial sum of F f (x). Moreover, (Parseval’s indentity) 1 L ∫ L −L |f (x)| 2dx = 2|a0| 2 + ∞∑ n=1 (|an| 2 + |bn| 2) . For f (x) deﬁned in [0, L], its cosine and sine series are (a0 = 1 L ∫ L 0 f (x) dx) Cf (x) = a0 + ∞∑ n=1 an cos( nπx L ), an = 2 L ∫ L 0 f (x) cos( nπx L ) dx, 1 Sf (x) = ∞∑ n=1 bn sin( nπx L ), bn = 2 L ∫ L 0 f (x) sin( nπx L ) dx. The coeﬃcients are those for Fourier series multiplied by 2, and the integra- tion is over [0, L]. Both Cf (x) and Sf (x) are deﬁned for all real x and are 2L-periodic. Cf (x) is even while Sf (x) is odd. Sine series on [0, L]: 1 = ∑ m is odd 4 mπ sin mπx L , x = ∞∑ m=1 2L mπ (−1) m+1 sin mπx L , x(L − x) = ∑ m is odd 8L 2 (mπ)3 sin mπx L . Heat and wave equations on a line [0, L] For f (x) deﬁned for x ∈ [0, L], let sin[f, n] and cos[f, n] denote its sine series and cosine series coeﬃcients, respectively. Heat eq. ut = c 2uxx, u(x, 0) = f (x) and 0-BC: u(x, t) = ∞∑ n=1 bn sin nπx L e −c 2n2π2t/L 2, bn = sin[f, n]. Heat eq. ut = c 2uxx, u(x, 0) = f (x) and 0-ﬂux BC: u(x, t) = a0 + ∞∑ n=1 an cos nπx L e −c 2n2π2t/L 2, an = cos[f, n]. Wave eq. utt = c 2uxx, u(x, 0) = f (x), ut(x, 0) = g(x) and 0-BC: u(x, t) = ∞∑ n=1 sin nπx L (An cos cnπt L + Bn sin cnπt L ) where An = sin[f, n] and cnπ L Bn = sin[g, n]. Heat and wave equations on a rectangle [0, a] × [0, b] Let sin[f, m, n] denote the double sine series coeﬃcents of f (x, y), sin[f, m, n] = 4 ab ∫ a 0 ∫ b 0 f (x, y) sin mπx a sin nπy b dy dx. Heat eq. ut = c 2(uxx + uyy), u(x, y, 0) = f (x, y) and 0-BC: u(x, y, t) = ∞∑ m,n=1 Bm,n sin mπx a sin nπy b e −c 2π2( m2 a2 + n2 b2 )t, Bm,n = sin[f, m, n]. Wave eq. utt = c 2(uxx + uyy), u(t = 0) = f , ut(t = 0) = g and 0-BC: u(x, y, t) = ∞∑ m,n=1 sin mπx a sin nπy b (Am,n cos µm,nt + Bm,n sin µm,nt) µm,n = cπ√ m2 a2 + n2 b2 , Am,n = sin[f, m, n] and µm,nBm,n = sin[g, m, n]. d’Alembert’s formula The solution to utt = c 2uxx, u(t = 0) = f , ut(t = 0) = g is u(x, t) = 1 2 [f (x + ct) + f (x − ct)] + 1 2c ∫ x+ct x−ct g(s) ds = Uleft(x + ct) + Uright(x − ct) where Uleft(y), Uright(y) = 1 2 f (y) ± 1 2c ∫ y 0 g(s) ds. Laplace equation and Poisson equation The solution u(x, y) for ∆u = 0 in Ω = {(x, y)| 0 ≤ x ≤ a, 0 ≤ y ≤ b} with BC u(a, y) = fR(y), u(0, y) = fL(y), u(x, 0) = 0 = u(x, b) is u(x, y) = ∞∑ n=1 sin nπy b ( Bn sinh nπx b sinh nπa b + ˜Bn sinh nπ(a−x) b sinh nπa b ) where Bn and ˜Bn are coeﬃcients of sine series of fR and fL, respectively. The eigenfunctions and eigenvalues for −∆u = λu in Ω with 0-BC are ϕm,n = sin mπx a sin nπy b , λm,n = (mπ/a) 2 + (nπ/b) 2. If f (x, y) = ∑∞ m,n=1 Am,nϕm,n in Ω, the solution for ∆u = f in Ω with 0-BC is u = ∑∞ m,n=1 −Am,n λm,n ϕm,n. Sturm-Liouville Eigenvalue Problems ODE: [p(x)y′] ′ + [q(x) + λr(x)]y = 0, a < x < b. BC: c1y(a) + c2y′(a) = 0, d1y(b) + d2y′(b) = 0. Hypothesis: p, p′, q, r continuous on [a, b]. p(x) > 0 and r(x) > 0 for x ∈ [a, b]. c 2 1 + c 2 2 > 0. d2 1 + d2 2 > 0. Properties (1) The diﬀerential operator Ly = [p(x)y′] ′ + q(x)y is symmetric in the sense that (f, Lg) = (Lf, g) for all f, g satisfying the BC, where (f, g) = ∫ b a f (x)g(x) dx. (2) All eigenvalues are real and can be ordered as λ1 < λ2 < 2 · · · < λn < · · · with λn → ∞ as n → ∞, and each eigenvalue admits a unique (up to a scalar factor) eigenfunction ϕn. (3) Orthogonality: (ϕm, rϕn) = ∫ b a ϕm(x)ϕn(x)r(x) dx = 0 if λm ̸= λn. (4) Expansion: If f (x) : [a, b] → R is square integrable, then f (x) = ∞∑ n=1 cnϕn(x), a < x < b , cn = ∫ b a f (x)ϕn(x)r(x) dx ∫ b a ϕ2 n(x)r(x) dx , n = 1, 2, . . .
